mediaNotes: Calls from an adult male on territory; subspecies microrhyncha?. Elevation: 224 m. Date added to IBC: June 22, 2016.

NOTES: Same bird as that highlighted in cut #2000-14-09, a male that was well seen (apparently an adult but it lacked tail streamers) perched and foraging about 8 meters away and 5-6 meters up in canopy of 7-8 meter tall trees with large white flowers at edge of campina 30 meters from the stream (essentially in the backyard of the house); this was recorded following playback of itself, in response to which the bird chipped more and flew back-and-forth; fully overcast most of the time, intermittent light rain and thunder, calm, 86-87¡ F. Response to playback: Approach. Response to playback: Normal song. Other Behaviors: Advertise. Habitat: Rainforest, Evergreen Forest, Creek, Savannah, Scrub, Edge.

NOTES: Neotropical Institute Cut # 1. Bulk reel: 408a) Natural "calls" (= song?). (In background is Coryphotriccus parvus [Conopias parva]. Quality: 1. Level: +10.b) Natural "calls" (= song?) by male and then vocalizations with female too. Quality: 1-2, 1. Level +10.c) After an interruption, while I recorded Euphonia chrysopasta, this is more of same as in b) but in addition some "wing-whirr" displays by male. A female was present and she also made bit of "wing-whirr." This recording continues as Cut 16) of Euphonia chrysopasta. Quality: 1. Level: +10.d) After playback, excited calling. At one time there were at least three males sitting close together and calling excitedly at each other. None of these appear to have the typical long tail. Therefore to be sure of identification, I collected one male (#6653) and one female (#6649). The latter was in good fresh plumage but the male was in full molt and no doubt the others were too. Quality: 1. Level: +10. Sound stimulation was (other): playback.

location.locality: 8 km. by road W Porto Grande, Recanto Ecologico Sonho Meu

mediaNotes:
NOTES: Song of same bird as cut #98RDAT15-18.  In canopy of riparian forest along a medium-sized, blackwater stream; unseen, but a male (possibly an immature) Topaza pella was seen briefly in this same spot (with its chipping heard at the end of this cut); 25-30 meters overhead; natural song after our approach to the spot; scattered clouds, hazy sunshine, 80¡ F.  COULD THIS BE Amazilia versicolor??

ML: Background subject changed from recordist's original identification of Vireo olivaceus chivi to Vireo olivaceus chivi/diversus to conform to eBird Taxonomy (v. 1.55). -Jay McGowan/Matt Medler, July 2015. Other Behaviors: Advertise. Habitat: Rainforest, Evergreen Forest, Creek, Riparian.
Flight / Alarm calls of two males fighting.

Vocalizava próximo à borda da mata ripária de igarapé, respondeu muito bem ao playback. Indivíduo defendia flores vermelhas, próximo a frutos também vermelhos semelhantes ao anani. Gravação na presença de Leonardo Victor.
